title: `rspsp`: Spatial Spectral Analysis in R
text: Test equal spectra either using one test.periodo() test.spectral(). can also visualize distribution randomized samples L_2 type test T_n (see test_spectral() detail):
code: y <- gridMA(75, 75, K0)  # apply periodogram based test Scaccia and Marin (2005) summary(test.periodo(x, y, .05)) #> Periodogram Test for equality Hypothesis.  #> ========================================= #> alpha: 0.05  #>  #>  #> Results  #> ----------------------------------------- #> Tn: -1.444126  #> p: 0.9256483  #> Decision: Accepted H0 # apply randomized test after Jentsch and Pauly (2015) res <- test.spectral(x, y, 300, .05) summary(res) #> Resampling Test for equality Hypothesis.  #> ========================================= #> Resampling iterations: 300  #> alpha: 0.05  #> used kernel-bandwith:  #>  h1: 0.05624503 h2: 0.05624503 #>  #> Results  #> ----------------------------------------- #> Tn: 27.18329  #> p: 0.7666667  #> Decision: Accepted H0 plot(res)

title: `rspsp`: Spatial Spectral Analysis in R
text: test.spectral() applicable hypothesis modelling assumptions. want test weak isotropy simply set hypothesis="isotropy" now consider non-isotropic process: …test reject:  can also test weak stationarity using hypothesis=stationary
code: # make sure to pass NULL for y res <- test.spectral(x, NULL, 300, .05, hypothesis="isotropy")  summary(res) #> Resampling Test for isotropy Hypothesis.  #> ========================================= #> Resampling iterations: 300  #> alpha: 0.05  #> used kernel-bandwith:  #>  h1: 0.05624503 h2: 0.05624503 #>  #> Results  #> ----------------------------------------- #> Tn: 18.77008  #> p: 0.9266667  #> Decision: Accepted H0 plot(res) x <- gridMA(50, 50, MA_coef_row(.7)) image(I(x)) res <- test.spectral(x, NULL, 300, .05, hypothesis="isotropy") #> Warning in test.spectral(x, NULL, 300, 0.05, hypothesis = "isotropy"): Kernel #> smoothed just one summand. Critical values broke, because Tn is invariant #> against permutation. summary(res) #> Resampling Test for isotropy Hypothesis.  #> ========================================= #> Resampling iterations: 300  #> alpha: 0.05  #> used kernel-bandwith:  #>  h1: 0.07369985 h2: 0.07369985 #>  #> Results  #> ----------------------------------------- #> Tn: 15.71547  #> p: 0  #> Decision: Rejected H0  plot(res) h <- length(x)^(-.2) res <- test.spectral(x, NULL, 300, .05, hypothesis="stationary", h1=h, h2=h)  summary(res) #> Resampling Test for stationary Hypothesis.  #> ========================================= #> Resampling iterations: 300  #> alpha: 0.05  #> used kernel-bandwith:  #>  h1: 0.2091279 h2: 0.2091279 #>  #> Results  #> ----------------------------------------- #> Tn: 1.491642  #> p: 0.8066667  #> Decision: Accepted H0 plot(res)

title: Correlated MA process — mvgridMA
text: simulationstudy also aim find sample correlation affects nominal size power tests. MA-process introduces correlation two levels: Innovations whole lattices. , first simulate two correlated white noise lattices \(\{\epsilon_i^{(1)}|\\mathbb Z^2\}\) \(\{\epsilon_i^{(2)}|\\mathbb Z^2\}\) : $$\begin{pmatrix}\epsilon_i^{(1)}\\ \epsilon_i^{(2)}\end{pmatrix}\overset{iid}\sim\mathcal N(0, \Sigma)$$ \(\Sigma = \begin{pmatrix}1 & \sigma\\ \sigma & 1 \end{pmatrix}\) two univariate moving average randomfieds simulated function convoluted white noise (\(K_0, K_1\)) ,also correlated counterparts (\(K_{0_{}}, K_{1_{}}\)): $$X_i^{(1)} = \sum_{j}\epsilon_{-j}^{(1)}K_{0,j} + \sum_l \epsilon_{-l}^{(2)}K_{0_{}, l}$$ analogous \(X_i^{(2)}\).

what: Periodogram Test for Assessing Equality of Spectral Densities — test.periodo
title: Periodogram Test for Assessing Equality of Spectral Densities — test.periodo
text: \(\varphi_n^p\) adaption test \(T_3\) work Scaccia Martin (2005). test compares individual deviations periodogram ordinates  \(I_x\) \(I_y\) total amplitude \(I_x + I_y\). define \(G(\omega_{kl})\) comparison value:  $$G(\omega_{kl}) = \frac{I_x(\omega_{kl})-I_y(\omega_{kl})}{I_x(\omega_{kl}) + I_y(\omega_{kl})}$$  test statistic \(PT_3\) given :  $$PT_3 = \sqrt{12n}(\overline{|G|-1/2}) \overset d\longrightarrow \mathcal N(0,1)$$  Critical values drawn standard normal distirbution.
